comments.commentBody: The real tragedy in all of this is while we wring our hands trying to connect all of the Russia dots, Trump is about to unleash a slew of executive orders that pose an even greater threat to our democracy.  I do not mean to be dismissive of the Russia scandal.  It should be investigated aggressively and exhaustively.  I just shudder when I think of what chaos Trump is about to unleash : anti-pollution regulations gutted, mass deportations, a new healthcare plan that rewards the rich and the healthy while neglecting the most vulnerable, a school system designed for Christian fundamentalists and science deniers, and an Attorney General's Office that shows no interest in protecting the rights of minorities.  Scariest of all, the feckless GOP stands idly by watching the train wreck.

Mossad spy to spy insult: May I read about you in the papers.

Putin is determined to Make Russia Great Again. Key to his ambition is the reacquisition of territories occupied by the former USSR. Hence his armed occupation Crimea. But before he can exert greater military force he must neutralize the opposition. That means weaken the NATO alliance, disrupt the EU, foment instability in individual western European democracies. Simply put: divide and conquer. He facilitates these ends by promoting nationalistic/isolationist right wing politics in western european democracies and the USA. Western security services report that Trumps’ win, Brexit, and the pending elections in France and Germany have all been subjected to surreptitious Russian electioneering.

In the short run, Putin seeks elimination of the crippling economic sanctions imposed by Obama in response to his annexation of Crimean and to avoid a more muscular in-kind response to his increasing military assertiveness. In contrast to Trumps stated friendly intentions, neither of these goals would likely have been achieved under a Clinton administration. All the better if they possess “kompromat” on Trump.

Trumps unexpected victory was an windfall for the Kremlin and an embarrassment for the USA. Moscow is enjoying this. However, these disclosures of FSB ‘sources and methods’ (in part by clumsy spy craft) limit Putins’ gain and will render future similar efforts more precarious. That, for Russia, is a disappointment.

It's really difficult --although not entirely impossible-- to believe that all Trump wanted to do, from deep in his heart, was to improve American- Russian relations. But this is where the ignorant amateur with a big mouth has almost certainly completely ruined the prospect for better relations any time soon.

When is Trump going to learn that there was always a reason for Political Correctness? ..that every word he speaks or tweets matters? ...that being President is really really hard work and is not a job you do by gut-reaction but by long hard deliberation on an endless list of pros and cons that should guide you in everything you do and and every last word you say?

Odds are almost certainly better that he won't last four years than he will finally and truly meet the very very high bar of being Presidential. (there are millions of Americans who could have done as good or a better job of delivering a TelePrompter speech in Congress. That doesn't make you a leader. It makes you a reader.)

It appears as though Trump is going to achieve what Hillary set out to do... he's breaking the glass ceiling from the other side and falling through. Oprah for President anyone?

Looking at the extensive business connections and backgrounds of his team members and their deep and complicated histories / relationships with Russia, I strongly disagree that one could ever assume that this was simply based on misguided efforts to build good will between nations. Best case scenario (and I use that loosely here, since calling this "best" hardly seems appropriate) seems to be that it all could boil down to the almighty dollar. Worst case scenario seems to be that it may turn out to have been a more hostile and all-encompassing foreign takeover attempt by Russia.

How far down does this matryoshka doll set travel within the Trump Administration? Lift one doll and there's another hidden inside. Is it reasonable to expect transparency in Cabinet and Staff that avoids the taint of impropriety? Three years, 11 months and 28 days on the clock.
Liar liar pants on fire . Burn the letters. I am not a criminal.  Instead of I have a dream.

In my book, this is just one more "ZERO-TO-IT" news story with invisible legs supported by cold war mentality crutches the vast majority of us cast off years ago.

Go find some real news, NYT. As Trump says, you are failing, because you fail your oldest readership for the naive millennial crowd.

There is way too many aspects of our government and our lives that are being addressed in an extremely small amount of time. It would seem to me it is a strategy to make it impossible for people to get a footing on how to respond.

For instance, I feel the EPA is influenced by corporate America and doesn't always do the right thing. And is bloated and costs too much money for failure. Can anyone honestly say that during their existence, the Environment has been protected? So…something needs to be done, but terminate? Investigation and discussion for probably 2 years would need to happen before any bill to make changes should be introduced.

Vouchers for Public Education - if everyone wants a voucher - what is going to happen to the public school system? The problem is, all these private schools have proliferated, because the federal government is overstepping and schools should be left to local control. At least that is one of the main problems. Which affects the Dept of Education…

Smaller government. When the Democrats can join Republicans to consider that a goal and contribute to figuring out how to reduce government, maybe we could get somewhere. It would seem to me that you are seeing this aggressive agenda from the Trump administration as a reaction to Democratic policy that has created massive, unresponsive, out of control government.
Only one problem.... Hillary's private email server actually existed!

The following quote from this article, talking about what has emerged from an entire compilation of the various media sources, really summarizes where the matter stands:

"There have been courtesy calls, policy discussions and business contacts, though nothing has emerged publicly indicating anything more sinister. "

Until something more "sinister" can be discovered what is the purpose in continuing the enslaught of innuendo and implied judgement?
Where are you getting your information?  Just curious.
Who knew Melania was such a genius? Smart enough not to pack and UPACK so soon.

Russian contacts?,,, nahhhhh. Nothing to see here. Move along everyone. This is just yet another case of "fake news".

And he is still America's President?

So SAD!!!!!!!

Two competing visions. One the US and Russia in constant conflict over who will cause the most damage, exercise the greater global control and will be the most feared. The other Russia and the US in partnership agreeing to coordinate efforts to dominate the world together, creating global misery in tandem.

James -- Putin's Russia seized Crimea. They are supporting a clandestine pro-Russian separatist army in Ukraine. They are Assad's ally in Syria.

They hacked the US election, clearly attempting to damage HRC and the Democrats, and install Trump.

And you are going to tell me that we "are beginning to out-Russian the Russians?"

You are "sick of the Russia bashing?" Really? You support what Russia has done?

The plain truth of the matter is that the US has installed a neo-fascist oligarch, who is trying to cement a transition to Putin-style authoritarianism in the USA. There's a whole lot to bash ... Trump and the Russians. And this is not a new cold war that the US started.

I guess I'm the outlier here, because I found this piece to be a bit cringey. I'm sorry for the writer's troubles, and I appreciate that she wrote this with love, appreciation and nothing but good wishes for her spouse. But I take issue with the conceit -- a writer's device, really -- of her playing the yenta for her soon-to-be-widower husband. Selling his good points. For me it crosses a line, somehow, perhaps there is a whiff of possession lurking behind the words. This is my husband, in all his glory, and I am gifting him to you. But he is not a possession to be passed along, like a beloved, old dog. How would this go over if a man wrote it about his wife, I wonder. I suspect it would raise some feminist hackles.

You are right about "feminist hackles." The most "liked" comment on this article managed to conclude that the husband was only worthwhile because she, the wife, had made him so.  Think about that, without the woman, the husband wouldn't be worthwhile.  Proof that sexism only works when wielded by women.
I too found this piece to be cringe-worthy.  I would not have wanted my late great husband to put me on the auction block!
Is North Korea going to be the Cuba of 2017? At least with the latter, there were intelligent people in government and some with cooler heads who prevailed.

Plennie,

The ballistic missile subs of the old CCCP had several levels of political officers on board. They were armed and in the "launch loop". While the Officers and crews were very brave to even go to sea in those subs, they were not stupid. There was no order given to launch anything on either side.
You're using elitist alternative facts.  Unfair!

John Ryan: "I guess that's a typical leftie slap at Trump."

Trump doesn't need any help from the left. He slaps himself around plenty.

However it is not ideological to say that he is a malignant narcissist who's entire view of whether something is good or bad, virtuous or vice, is whether or not he subjectively believes it is good for himself, Trump, or not. Inside Trump's head, everything, the sun, the moon and the earth, orbit around him.

Psychologically the guy is a dysfunctional idiot with the attention span of a gnat. 9 years ago George Bush was the worst president in American history, or at least since Buchanan. Now Bush looks Churchillian next to the bump named Trump. But don't worry. 9 years after Trump is gone, the Republicans will hoist upon America some other bozo that will make Trump look respectable too. There ability to find new lows is truly amazing.

Page views. Clicks. Comments. People like to read sad stories, and then tell their own tales in the comment section.

I don't like it so much myself, but that's just my vote.

Easily the nicest thing I've read in the last two years.

Thank you.

Dear Amy,

Your beautiful, heartfelt words keep replaying in my head. They take me back to an afternoon 7 1/2 years ago when my husband, so thin and so sick, suffering from the effects of throat cancer, chemo and radiation staring out the door. He turned to me, hugged me and said "I don't think I'm going to make it, Honey . I want you to have a happy life." I sobbed. I could see it in his eyes. I could hear it in his voice. He meant it from the bottom of his heart. Several weeks later, he was gone. I miss seeing his sweet face, hearing his laughter and most of all, I miss his hugs. He gave the best hugs. Jason will miss all of the things that are so special about your marriage. He will cherish them and draw strength from them. How selfless of you to put your heart and soul out to the Universe in search of your wish for Jason to have a
happy life. I am still in the process of developing a new normal in my life. It may always be that way. My kids are grown with their own families. I am single but I'm ok with that. I compare and they are some really big shoes to fill. I am lucky. I experienced a love many people will never know.
I surround myself with friends, family and people who bring joy to my world. I am living a happy life . I think my husband would agree. God bless you and your sweet, loving family. You are making every minute of the rest of your life
count. I admire you. You are a strong woman with a BIG heart.

Dear Amy,

You are the voice of many women stricken with life threatening disease. Lucid and poignant is your writing. Know that the life you have given and lived and shared will never die.
Bless you for your inner strength and concern for others. Thank heaven for forever.
Yours,
Susan

I just retired a few days ago after teaching for 26 years.  When the NY times articles about 403b's were published last summer, I contacted my AXA advisor who immediately set up an appointment with my husband and I to explain the fees, the articles,  and different options for my retirement plan.  With my guaranteed interest rate fund there are NO fees at all!  As far as the other ones, they are modest and reasonable considering my advisor is a phone call or email away.  He always comes to my home and drove down to my mother's to discuss some of her options after my Dad died (he relied on bank interest for income which worked in previous years but not today).  Like my Dad always said, "you get what you pay for" and I have been very satisfied with my AXA advisor.

I'm with Ron. One of the insurance industry's big lies about "investment products" is "you don't pay me, the firm does." If you want to get a decent idea about an agents commission just ask "how much will I get back if I want to get all my money out the first year." This "surrender charge" is often the exact amount of gross commission paid by the insurance company.
If you want advice that is more likely to be in your best interests ask your advisor if they are ALWAYS required to act as your fiduciary - then ask for it in writing. Bet your insurance salesman will refuse to do so.

Many 403(b) accounts contact fixed accounts and some have guarantees with 3 or 4% minimums (especially older ones).  There are no fees deducted from these accounts and the interest rate stated is the interest rate given.  In this interest rate environment, it's a much better place to have safe money as opposed to the low interest rate/high risk of longer term bonds (IMHO).  It's where my wife has her money invested.  By your response, you aren't even aware of this benefit in some 403(b)s.  Perhaps better reporting is in order in the future.

replies.commentBody: I would never dare to assume that I (or readers) know all of the facts about all of the plans -- or even the facts of their own plans, given how complicated they are and all of the various ways that fees, surrender charges and other costs that have different names are attached to the accounts. Same way that I'd never assume that I could guess where the bond market is headed and make proportionate bets accordingly. I'm just trying to encourage the asking of inconvenient questions and radical humility about our ability to divine the answers and predict what the markets will do (while keeping in mind that a 3 or 4 percent guaranteed return may not be enough over time to provide a comfortable retirement, depending on your circumstances).

Ron Leiber - 3 or 4 percent guaranteed is in my opinion quite poor in the long run. Three is around the level of inflation in normal times which means you're doing no more than treading water. Decent retirement savings are predicated on the impact of long-term quality investments, and 3 percent is not going to cut it.

Not being a teacher, when I move jobs unless something is a particularly good set of investment options I regularly shift my 401k into better options - rarely do I agree with the actively-managed funds with high-management fees involved that have been selected. (I have no formal training or ties into financial markets; it is all from what I have learned on my own over years of reading and paying attention - unfortunately no one can do that for you)

comments.commentBody: All funds have management fees, and I know the amount of each and every one of my mutual fund investments (index funds included) - Vanguard does not in most funds that I am aware of charge separate fees for withdrawing (or investing).  I suspect Kathleen Hewins is not aware of the management fees as they are baked into the percent earned.
I'm glad your adviser was so responsive. Did you ask how he and the company are making money if there are no fees at all? Even Vanguard charges fees.

This whole Russia connection situation is exhausting.  It wears me out.  But we must get to the bottom of it.  Not only do we have the usual partisan opposition to seeking the truth, we have a president who lies on an almost a daily basis, and his base who views those seeking the truth as "snowflake crybabies" while willing to believe the most preposterous fake news.  It is going to be a long haul.  We must be prepared for it.

Thanks, Ms. Collins for adding Cleveland to Las Vegas as a place where so many of the rules of so-called good behaviour don't apply, although meeting with the ambassador of a foreign power connected to interfering with a presidential election sure sounds like less fun than what Las Vegas offers.

The latest line from Republicans seems to be that Russia is being picked on when Democrats and all reasonable citizens are calling for a special investigation into Russia's role in Trump's victory.

While it is easy to detect more than a whiff of white supremacist thinking (Imagine the GOP outcry if the Chinese were accused!), all patriotic Americans should be outraged that any foreign power tampered with this important election. That Trump and many of his so-called businessmen supporters have economic ties to Russia which were not allowed to be vetted should be very concerning to all who voted for Trump. Why isn't it?

Rachel Maddow has been following the adventures of a Russian oligarch known as the "fertilizer King" who bought a rather large and undesirable property off Trump's hands. overpaid and handed Trump a $60 million profit just when Trump desperately needed  the money.
